Regarding brothers of the same family, there is a principle that 'the first son succeeds to his family's own Myoseki, and the second son or smaller succeeds to the other family's Myoseki,' and therefore, it may happen unexpectedly that 'his younger brother has a higher-ranked Myoseki.'

Furthermore, there is a principle regarding brothers of the same family whereby the first son inherits his family's own Myoseki, whereas the second son inherits the Myoseki name/title of another family'.

sen.j: 肉親及び親類が実子または養子として家名を継ぐことを「家督を継ぐ」というが、血縁でないものが娘婿（婿養子）あるいは養子となって家名を踏襲する場合は「名跡を継ぐ」ということもある。
sen.e: When an immediate family member or blood-related relative succeeds to his family name as a real son or an adopted son, this act is expressed as 'to succeed the family estate,' while an unrelated person takes over the family name as son-in-law (by marrying into his wife's family) or as an adopted son, this is sometimes expressed as 'to succeed to the predecessors' Myoseki.'
sen.cmt: 「家督を継ぐ」→定訳不明：'to succeed the family estate'としました。「名跡を継ぐ」→定訳不明：'to succeed to the predecessors' Myoseki'としました。
sen.e: When an immediate family member or blood-related relative succeeds to his family name as a real son or an adopted son, this act is expressed as 'to succeed the family estate,' while an unrelated person takes over the family name as son-in-law (by marrying into his wife's family) or as an adopted son, this is sometimes expressed as 'to succeed to the predecessors' Myoseki.'

When an immediate family member or blood-related relative inherits his family name as either a biological or alternatively an adopted son, this process is termed as inheriting the family estate,' whereas, when an unrelated person takes over the family name as son-in-law (by marrying into his wife's family) or as an adopted son, this is sometimes termed 'inheriting a predecessors' Myoseki.'

sen.j: 鎌倉時代以降、家名が絶えた場合にその断絶を惜しみ、肉親以外のものが称す場合があり、さらには戦勝の記念として滅ぼした敵の家名を名乗るという事例もあるという。
sen.e: Since the Kamakura Period, in case that there was no heir to carry on a family's name, sometimes an unrelated person, who felt sorry for the family's discontinuance, took over the name, and moreover, there were some cases in which the person who destroyed a family in the battle took over the name of this destroyed family as a trophy.

Since the Kamakura Period, in case there was no heir to carry on a family's name, sometimes an unrelated person, who felt sorry for the family's discontinuance, took over the name, and moreover, there were some cases in which the person who destroyed a family in battle took over the name of this destroyed family as a trophy.

From the Kamakura period onwards, when there was no heir to carry on a family's name, sometimes an unrelated person, who sympathized with the family's situation (discontinuation), assumed (`adopted`) the name, and moreover, there were cases where victors who destroyed a family in battle appropriated the vanquished family's name as a trophy.
